results.title: Frameworks in action: active learning
results.creator_credit: Chris O'Rourke and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Three teachers show their approach to “active learning” in areas of primary English, postprimary Mathematics and Drama. This is part of a series showing teachers and parents practical responses to the Frameworks approach.

results.title: Frame by frame: the art of animation
results.creator_credit: Jerry Samuelson, Paul Burnford, Paul Burnford Film Productions and Pyramid Films
results.brief_description: This film explores the possibilities of making a frame-by-frame, or animated film. Illustrates a variety of frame-by-frame techniques: still-picture filming (kinestasis), flicker-framing, cut-out animation, people animation (pixillation), direct images on film, and time sequence filming. This film is suitable for upper secondary levels.

results.title: Fracture of the cervical spine: crutchfield tongs reduction
results.brief_description: A silent film with intertitles showing the way crutchfield tongs reduction works to cure a patient who has fractured his cervical spine after diving into shallow water. The initial operation in which the head is drilled is shown performed on a cadaver.

results.title: Foxbat and the Mimi
results.creator_credit: John Skibinski and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A storm forces a flying fox to take shelter in a cave, something he regrets when cave spirits attempt to capture him. A film by John Skibinski. Also available as a compilation with “The Huge adventures of Trevor the cat”.

results.title: Fox and the jug
results.creator_credit: St Latal, Czechoslovak State Film and Official Films
results.brief_description: An animated version of the fable. A sly fox is looking for an easy dinner. An innocent looking jug upsets his plans and the little red rooster lives to run another day.

results.title: Fourteenth Biennial Conference - British Empire Service League
results.creator_credit: Returned Services League of Australia and University of Melbourne
results.brief_description: Documents the Fourteenth Biennial Conference of the British Empire Service League held at the Albert Hall in Canberra in 1958. Shows footage of the Queen Mother placing a wreath on the Canberra War Memorial and opening the Conference.

results.title: Fourteen Days in May
results.brief_description: In May 1987, Edward Earl Johnson, a black American convicted of murdering a white town marshal, was executed. This haunting document follows the last day of his life. In the final days and hours of Johnson’s life, the filmmakers observed the lawyer’s desperate fight to save his client’s life, and it becomes obvious how the prison doctors, chaplain, wardens and other inmates feel both about Johnson’s guilt and about the death penalty itself.

results.title: Four seasons in the life of Ludovic
results.creator_credit: Co Hoedeman, Jean-Jacques Leduc and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A compilation of the complete series of Ludovic, an animated classic about a young teddybear. In “Snow Gift”, Ludovic watches the snow outside the thatched cottage in which he lives with his family and dreams of tobogganing with his friends. His parents tell him he is too little, and Ludovic feels lonely, so he invents wonderful games to share with his new found friend, a doll that came to life. In “A Crocodile in my Garden”, Ludovic organises his origami jungle animals to go on a spring picnic in his garden. The mood degenerates as the animals disobey Ludovic and fight but all is resolved happily when cookies are distributed and the animals learn to share. In “Visiting Grandpa” Ludovic spends the afternoon with Grandpa on the farm, tending the animals and the garden, and though they miss grandma very much they find that her magic is still around. In “Magic in the Air” Ludovic happily plays in the playground when another teddy tries to befriend him, or so he thinks until he is knocked to the ground. Ludovic is rescued by a smiling girl teddy. Ludovic and his new friend find ways to out-smart the bully. The leaves, the trees and even the sand castle help out and soon the bully leaves him alone. But the magic doesn’t stop there and soon it is used to help cheer up the mad and sad bully. Each episode is also available as separate titles.
